page.title: 03CROWLE MOORS
page.content: {Crowle Moors}stretch beyond the Western edge of this area. It is a forest and peat moor that goes back thousands of years.The{forest}at one time covered most of the higher land, including{Rainsbutt Farm.}It offered shelter and food to the{Ancient {Britons,}but was burnt down by the {Romans}as they cultivated the land and drove out the{Britons. To this day farmers pull out the blackened roots and trunks of giant bog oak trees. A reminder of Roman burnings. In{1959}the forest burnt down again. Since then it has fully recovered and supports a wealth of wild life. The {National Trust}presently leases partof this land for conservation. Besides the{sphagnum moss}, a whole host of wild plants, birds and animals may be observed there, eg. deer and adders.
